keyTakeAways: Former U.S. Representative George Santos was released from prison on October 18, 2025, after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos had been serving an 87-month (seven-year) prison term for aggravated identity theft and wire fraud related to fabricated biographical details during his 2022 campaign.
Santos was expelled from Congress in December 2023, making him only the sixth member of Congress ever to be expelled.
Santos admitted to fabricating parts of his employment and educational history, which led to public and political backlash.
Trump commuted the sentence citing Santos' prolonged solitary confinement and mistreatment, stating he 'does not believe' Santos should be 'lost in the system'.
Santos wrote an open letter to Trump pleading for 'fairness' and a chance to rebuild, asserting he takes full responsibility for his actions.

The commutation drew mixed reactions: some lawmakers, including Marjorie Taylor Greene, praised it as justice for mistreatment, while others like House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries criticized Trump for focusing on Santos rather than addressing healthcare issues.

Santos expressed gratitude to Republican lawmakers such as Marjorie Taylor Greene, Lauren Boebert, Anna Paulina Luna, and Matt Gaetz, as well as to DOJ officials including Todd Blanche, Diego Pestana, and Ed Martin.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former U.S. Representative George Santos, who was expelled from Congress in 2023 and convicted on fraud charges related to fabricated biographical details, was released from prison on October 18, 2025, after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence. The commutation came amid public and political controversy, with Trump citing mistreatment in solitary confinement and calling for 'fairness' and a chance for rehabilitation. Santos had previously pleaded guilty in August 2024 and expressed full responsibility for his actions, while also appealing for a second chance. The move drew praise from some Republican allies, including Marjorie Taylor Greene and others, who claimed Santos was unfairly treated, but criticism from Democratic leaders like House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, who argued Trump should have addressed broader national issues like healthcare. The case underscores tensions in U.S. politics over justice, accountability, and the role of presidential clemency.
title: Former Rep. George Santos Released from Prison After Trump Commutes Sentence
